> But you see IEC always turns into the type of IEC I'm talking about
> if it is the kind of collaborative branch-based IEC in Picbreeder
> because it is impossible for the system as a whole to be driven by a
> particular goal.  The worst that can happen is that an individual
> user simply doesn't publish something because their personal goal
> wasn't satisfied.  However, that has no effect on the collective
> dynamic, which is that what *is* published is fodder for everything
> else.

Ok. I was focused more on your human in the loop, not your Web 2.0 humans in
the loop. I see where you are coming from.

> I do consider Golem to be TBE, yes, because it has an explicit
> goal.  Sure, there are many ways to achieve the goal, but the goal
> is what makes it TBE.

Yeah, but life (and picbreeder images) have a goal too: yield lots o copies.

> Actually this project does use almost the exact same encoding as
> Picbreeder, which is why I mentioned it.  It uses DelphiNEAT, which
> is where the idea for CPPNs was inspired.  I guess I'm not sure what
> you mean when you say you don't see the difference between this and
> Picbreeder, where we have distinct objects like cars, insects, and
> faces.  You don't a see difference between those pictures and the
> ones on this site?

I do see this difference (the lack of recognizable objects) now that you
point it out. I also agree that the lack of them is probably due to the
averaging. But I wonder whether each user has a short term goal for a while
that allows them to go off in a direction towards something they glimpsed in
a pattern. I see something like a car and I keep selecting for the
car-looking images till I get the image. That can't happen in the Delphi
project cause my desire to go off in a direction is prevented by the group.
If I am on the right track, then maybe the branching possibilities are more
the key ingredient in the difference between the projects than the
goallessness. But I also agree that many users do not have goals (or keep
them around for long). So there is a lot of selection for abstract things
like coolness, complexity, and whatever makes up our concepts of beautiful,
interesting, etc. 

Anyway, I understand why you made your original claim. I agree with you that
some of the elements of the type of IEC to which you refer are analogous to
some of the elements of natural selection. :-)
